page.title: 19Local history, Faceby (p.i)
page.content: {Faceby}derives from Feitr, a personal name, and the Danish "by" and has been translated as "Fatty's Farm".{Swainby} is also thought to derive from a personal name, Sveyn.{Whorlton,}the "Wirueltune" of Domesday Book, comes from the old Norse "hverfill" a rounded hilltop and the Saxon "ton", the settlement under a round hill. This area is associated with{Roman {occupation.}A hoard of silver ornaments and coins was ploughed up on Whorl Hill in 1810, dated well after AD 402, and when Whorlton churchyard was extended in 1907 and again in 1977 fragments of Roman pottery dating AD 300-407 were found each time, suggesting a Roman settlement nearby. Pieces of mediaeval pottery were also found. Proof of pre-Conquest occupation lies in the{Iron Age}fort and field system on Live Moor.
